{{Infobox venue | stadium_name = HighPoint.com Stadium | nickname = The Birthplace of College Football | image = [[File:RUFootballStadium.jpg|250px]] | address = 1 Scarlet Knight Way | location = [[Piscataway, New Jersey]] | coordinates = {{coord|40|30|49|N|74|27|55|W|type:landmark|display=it}} | broke_ground = March 9, 1993 | opened = September 3, 1994 | closed = | demolished = | former names = Rutgers Stadium (1994–2011) High Point Solutions Stadium (2011-2017) | operator = Rutgers University | architect = GSGSBH{{cite book |title=Piscataway Township|last=Gabrielan|first=Randall|year=2001|publisher=Arcadia Publishing|location=Charleston, South Carolina|isbn=0-7385-0439-4|page=114|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Sx24XbQ4N40C&pg=PA114 |accessdate=February 11, 2012}} | general_contractor= Terminal Construction Company | surface = [[FieldTurf]] (2004–present)
Natural grass (1994–2003) | construction_cost = $28 million
(${{formatprice|{{Inflation|US|28000000|1994}}}} in {{Inflation-year|US}} dollars{{inflation-fn|US}})
$102 million expansion | tenants = [[Rutgers Scarlet Knights]] ([[National Collegiate Athletic Association|NCAA]])
Football (1994–present)
Men's lacrosse (2014–present)
Women's lacrosse (2014–present) | seating_capacity = 41,500 (1994–2009)
52,454 (2009–present) |}} '''HighPoint.com Stadium''' is the [[college football|football]] [[stadium]] at [[Rutgers-New Brunswick|Rutgers University]] in [[Piscataway, New Jersey]]. It is located on the [[Busch Campus (Rutgers University)|Busch Campus]] at Rutgers, and overlooks the [[Raritan River]] to the South. The stadium was opened as ''Rutgers Stadium'' on September 3, 1994,{{cite web | title = Rutgers Stadium History : The New Stadium | work = The Official Site of Rutgers Athletics | publisher = Rutgers, The State University of New Jersey | url = http://www.scarletknights.com/football/history/stadium3.asp | accessdate = January 12, 2009 | archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20090429090313/http://www.scarletknights.com/football/history/stadium3.asp# | archive-date = 2009-04-29 | dead-url = yes | df = }} when the [[Rutgers Scarlet Knights]] hosted the [[Kent State University]] [[Kent State Golden Flashes|Golden Flashes]]. It currently seats 52,454 spectators after a 2009 expansion. ==Current facilities== HighPoint.com underwent significant reconstruction from 2008 to 2009 to increase its capacity to 52,454. The stadium features two 5,000-seat upper decks on each side of the playing field, as well as 968 [[Box (theatre)|loge]] and [[club seating|club seats]] on the [[Mezzanine (architecture)|mezzanine]] level of the East side of the stadium. A two-story press box sits on the mezzanine level of the West side of the stadium. Electronic ribbon scoreboards spanning the length of the field along the bottom of both upper decks were installed prior to the 2008 season, which complement the video [[scoreboard]] in the South end zone. Also located in the South end zone is the Brown Football Recruiting Pavilion and Welcome Center, part of the 2008–2009 expansion project. The stadium also features light stanchions that allow for night games, a [[cannon]] for firing when Rutgers scores, concessions, and restrooms. Until 2004, the field maintained a grass surface, but has since been replaced with [[Field Turf]]. ==History== The [[1869 college football season|first intercollegiate football game]], in which Rutgers beat [[Princeton University|Princeton]] 6–4 on November 6, 1869, was played at '''College Field''', which is now the location of the [[College Avenue Gymnasium]] and its parking lot.{{cite web | title = Rutgers Stadium History : The Early Years | work = The Official Site of Rutgers Athletics | publisher = Rutgers, The State University of New Jersey | url = http://scarletknights.com/football/history/stadium.asp | accessdate = January 12, 2009 | archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20090130012940/http://scarletknights.com/football/history/stadium.asp# | archive-date = 2009-01-30 | dead-url = yes | df = }} From 1891 to 1938, the Rutgers football team played at '''Neilson Field''' on the College Avenue Campus in [[New Brunswick, New Jersey]]. With the aid of grants from the [[Works Progress Administration]], and after three years of construction, the original [[Rutgers Stadium (1938)|Rutgers Stadium]] was completed in 1938. The first game in the new stadium was against [[Hampden–Sydney College|Hampden-Sydney]] in front of an estimated crowd of about 10,000 persons. Rutgers was victorious in the contest, defeating Hampden-Sydney 32–0.{{cite web | title = Rutgers Stadium History : The Depression Years | work = The Official Site of Rutgers Athletics | publisher = Rutgers, The State University of New Jersey | url = http://scarletknights.com/football/history/stadium1.asp | accessdate = January 12, 2009 | archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20081221021455/http://scarletknights.com/football/history/stadium1.asp# | archive-date = 2008-12-21 | dead-url = yes | df = }} The stadium was dedicated on November 5, 1938 in a game against Princeton. Rutgers would go on to win the game 20-18. It was the first time Rutgers had defeated Princeton since the first ever intercollegiate football game in 1869.{{cite web | title = Rutgers Stadium History : The Dedication Game Through the Centennial Game | work = The Official Site of Rutgers Athletics | publisher = Rutgers, The State University of New Jersey | url = http://www.scarletknights.com/football/history/stadium2.asp | accessdate = May 4, 2010 | archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20100113125935/http://scarletknights.com/football/history/stadium2.asp# | archive-date = 2010-01-13 | dead-url = yes | df = }} On September 27, 1969, Rutgers and Princeton met for The Centennial Game at old Rutgers Stadium, which was played in front of 31,000 fans. Rutgers would win 29-0, their 10th win in 60 tries against the Tigers. The current stadium was built on the site of the original old Rutgers Stadium. During the construction of the current stadium, the Rutgers Scarlet Knights football team played the [[1993 in sports|1993]] season at [[Giants Stadium]] in [[East Rutherford, New Jersey]], a facility operated by the [[New Jersey Sports and Exposition Authority]] (NJSEA). The NJSEA financed the construction of the stadium via the issuance of [[Bond (finance)|bonds]]. The Scarlet Knights had previously played several games at Giants Stadium, including the first college football game hosted at that venue: a 47-0 victory over [[Columbia University]] on October 23, 1976.{{cite news | last = White | first = Gordon S., Jr. | title = Passes Griffin as Pitt Rolls by 45-0; Rutgers Routs Columbia, 47-0, For 14 in Row | work = [[The New York Times]] | date = October 24, 1976 | url = http://select.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=F10F1EFD3B5D15768FDDAD0A94D8415B868BF1D3 | accessdate = January 12, 2009}} The new Rutgers Stadium was originally constructed to accommodate 41,500 fans at its maximum capacity and was officially opened on September 3, 1994, in a game against Kent State University. Light stanchions were integrated into the design so night games could be played. A two-story press box that fits 200 reporters was also constructed and is still in use today. A free-standing scoreboard was built near the south end zone, which did not originally contain any seating areas. The original design of the stadium replicated the shape of a [[horseshoe]], with the "open" end located near the south end zone. Heralded by many newspapers, sports writers, and Rutgers fans as the "most important game in Rutgers history", on November 9, 2006, a then record crowd of 44,111{{cite web | title = Rutgers Stadium Records | work = The Official Site of Rutgers Athletics | publisher = Rutgers, The State University of New Jersey | url = http://www.scarletknights.com/football/history/records-stadium.asp | accessdate = January 12, 2009 | archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20090907030707/http://www.scarletknights.com/football/history/records-stadium.asp# | archive-date = 2009-09-07 | dead-url = yes | df = }} attended a football game between the Scarlet Knights and the [[2006 Louisville Cardinals football team|Louisville Cardinals]] at Rutgers Stadium. The Scarlet Knights were ranked #15 and the Louisville Cardinals #3 in the nation in the [[2006 NCAA Division I FBS football rankings|Associated Press poll]] at the time. The game drew the ESPN's third-largest TV audience for a college football game up to that point in time.{{cite news| last = Hiestrand | first = Michael | title = NBC benefits from flexible Sunday night football scheduling | work = [[USA Today]] | date = November 13, 2006 | url = https://www.usatoday.com/sports/columnist/hiestand-tv/2006-11-13-flex-schedule_x.htm | accessdate = January 12, 2009}} The official attendance exceeded the normal maximum capacity of the stadium due to the temporary addition of bleachers in the South end zone of the stadium. The bleachers were used to seat additional students. ===Stadium expansion (2008–2009)=== [[File:Rutgers Stadium expansion.jpg|thumb|left|The exterior of the stadium's expansion seen from River Road, under construction on September 26, 2009.]] [[File:RutgersScoreboard.jpg|thumb|left|The newly expanded South End zone at Rutgers Stadium, pictured after the 2010 spring game. Note the Brown Football Recruiting Pavilion and Welcome Center located in the center of the seating area, as well as the brand new scoreboard.]] In January 2008, the Board of Governors of Rutgers University announced a $102 million stadium expansion project in order to increase the stadium's [[seating capacity]] to nearly 56,000.{{cite press release | title = Rutgers Board of Governors Approves Stadium Expansion | publisher = Rutgers, The State University of New Jersey | date = January 29, 2008 | url = http://www.scarletknights.com/football/news/release.asp?prID=6088 | accessdate = January 12, 2009 | archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20080623034459/http://www.scarletknights.com/football/news/release.asp?prID=6088# | archive-date = 2008-06-23 | dead-url = yes | df = }} However, the scale of the project was slightly reduced due to a poor economy and financial difficulties, resulting in a new maximum capacity of precisely 52,454. The first phase of the project, which included the addition 968 club seats and related infrastructure to the East mezzanine level of the stadium, was completed on time and within budget for the 2008 football season.{{cite press release | title = Statements from the Administration | publisher = Rutgers, The State University of New Jersey | date = December 12, 2008 | url = http://www.scarletknights.com/stadium/president.html | accessdate = January 12, 2009 | archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20090126074839/http://scarletknights.com/stadium/president.html# | archive-date = 2009-01-26 | dead-url = yes | df = }} The second phase included the addition of approximately 11,500 seats to the previously "open" South end zone, as well as supplementary restrooms and concession stands to the southern end of the stadium. The second phase of the project also involved the addition of a large scoreboard in the South end zone, which is 38' tall by 112' wide, for a total surface area of 4,256 sq ft.{{cite news | title = Rutgers Scoreboard Among Biggest in Country | publisher = MyCentralJersey | date = August 17, 2009 | url = http://blogs.mycentraljersey.com/rutgers/2009/08/17/rutgers-scoreboard-among-biggest-in-country/ | accessdate = May 4, 2010}} The old scoreboard (since demolished) was 22' tall by 30' wide, for a total surface area of {{convert|660|sqft|m2|abbr=on}}. The sound system was also enhanced as a part of the second phase of the expansion.{{cite web | title = Rutgers Stadium – Home of the Scarlet Knights | publisher = Rutgers, The State University of New Jersey | url = http://scarletknights.com/football/stadium/stadium.asp | accessdate = May 2, 2010 | archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20100502053653/http://www.scarletknights.com/football/stadium/stadium.asp# | archive-date = 2010-05-02 | dead-url = yes | df = }} In addition to adding seats, concession stands, and bathrooms to the south end zone, the stadium expansion project called for a new entrance off River Road. The facade of the entrance is adorned with [[brownstone]], and as of May 2, 2010, was not fully completed. ====Brown Football Recruiting Pavilion and Welcome Center==== On July 14, 2009, the Rutgers Board of Governors unanimously approved a $5 million donation specifically appropriated for a recruiting lounge in the newly expanded end zone. The lounge had been included in the original expansion design, but was later deferred after the Board of Governors revised the expansion financing plan. The donation was provided by two Rutgers alumni. The lounge was named after one of the donors, [[Greg Brown (businessman)|Greg Brown]], who is the President and Co-CEO of [[Motorola]]. The second donor requested anonymity. Construction on the lounge commenced in August 2009, and was completed in December of that same year.{{cite web | title = Rutgers approves privately funded recruiting lounge as part of football stadium expansion | publisher = The Star Ledger | url = http://www.nj.com/rutgersfootball/index.ssf/2009/07/rutgers_approves_privately_fun.html | accessdate = July 14, 2009}} The facility seats approximately 300 people and serves as a multi-purpose center for the university. The pavilion hosts and accommodates recruits around the year and also holds fundraising events for potential donors. The center is also used during tours for prospective students. ====Expansion financing plan==== The $102 million price tag of the expansion project was to originally be financed via private fundraising ($30 million) and the issuance of bonds ($72 million).{{cite press release | title = Statements from the Administration | publisher = Rutgers, The State University of New Jersey | date = January 29, 2008 | url = http://www.scarletknights.com/stadium/president.html | accessdate = January 12, 2009 | archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20090126074839/http://scarletknights.com/stadium/president.html# | archive-date = 2009-01-26 | dead-url = yes | df = }} The private fundraising effort, however, fell significantly short of the original goal.{{cite news | last = Sherman | first = Ted |author2=Margolin, Josh | title = Fundraising for Rutgers Stadium falls far short | work = [[The Star-Ledger]] | date = September 10, 2008 | url = http://www.nj.com/news/index.ssf/2008/09/a_private_fundraising_effort_t.html | accessdate = January 12, 2009}} This situation prompted the Board of Governors of Rutgers University to approve a new financing plan for the stadium expansion in which the entire amount of $102 million was to be borrowed. Specifically, the university issued $85 million in bonds, and borrowed the remaining $17 million by way of low-interest commercial paper. In addition, a few aspects of the stadium expansion project were scaled back, including a reduction in the number of new seats (the original plan called for 14,000 seats, but only 11,500 were actually added). Also included in the original expansion plan was the construction of new locker rooms in the South end zone. The construction of these locker rooms was deferred to a later date. ====Naming rights==== For decades, ''Rutgers Stadium'' had been the name of the school's football facility. However, in June 2010, Rutgers University put up for sale the naming rights to the stadium in order to bring in much needed revenue. Rutgers hired Brooklyn Sports & Entertainment and IMG College to act as agents in making a deal, who had previously negotiated deals on the now-[[Brooklyn Nets]]' home arenas in [[Izod Center|New Jersey]] and [[Barclays Center|New York]].{{cite web | title = Rutgers to sell naming rights to stadium, arena | work = NorthJersey.com | publisher = North Jersey Media Group Inc. | date = June 30, 2010 | url = http://www.northjersey.com/sports/063010_Rutgers_looking_to_name_stadium_athletic_center.html | accessdate = September 9, 2012}} On June 22, 2011, it was announced that High Point Solutions, based in Sparta, New Jersey, had purchased the rights, and that the stadium would be known as High Point Solutions Stadium. In May 2018, High Point Solutions announced they were rebranding the company to just be HighPoint.com. As a result, the name of the stadium was changed to HighPoint.com Stadium. ==Attendance records== [[File:Rutgers Stadium.jpg|thumb|Scarlet Knights vs. Cincinnati Bearcats with 43,768 spectators.]] The stadium attendance records were repeatedly broken throughout the 2006 and 2007 football seasons as the football program experienced a drastic resurgence. On October 18, 2007, a record 44,267 spectators attended a game in which the Scarlet Knights played against the then #2 ranked [[South Florida Bulls football|South Florida Bulls]].{{cite web | title = Rutgers Upends No. 2/3 South Florida 30-27 | work = Official Website of Rutgers Athletics. Rutgers | publisher = Rutgers, The State University of New Jersey | date = October 19, 2007 | url = http://scarletknights.com/football/news/release.asp?prID=5783 | accessdate = January 12, 2009 | archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20081216044058/http://www.scarletknights.com/football/news/release.asp?prID=5783# | archive-date = 2008-12-16 | dead-url = yes | df = }} The Scarlet Knights would go on to win that game, and the attendance on that night would be the highest ever prior to the 2008–2009 stadium expansion. The new record was set in the 2014 [[Big Ten Conference]] opener against the [[Penn State Nittany Lions football|Penn State]], when 53,774 people packed the venue to witness the first game in Big Ten Conference play after transferring from the [[American Athletic Conference]] before the 2014 season. This record still stands today. The top 5 games in terms of attendance at Rutgers Stadium are listed below: {| class="wikitable" ! style="{{CollegePrimaryStyle|Rutgers Scarlet Knights|color=#FFFFFF}};"|Rank!! style="{{CollegePrimaryStyle|Rutgers Scarlet Knights|color=#FFFFFF}};"|Attendance !! style="{{CollegePrimaryStyle|Rutgers Scarlet Knights|color=#FFFFFF}};"|Date !! style="{{CollegePrimaryStyle|Rutgers Scarlet Knights|color=#FFFFFF}};"|Game result |- | 1 || 53,774 (sell-out){{cite web | title = PENN STATE vs RUTGERS (Sep 13, 2014) | work = Official Website of Rutgers Athletics. | publisher = Rutgers, The State University of New Jersey | date = September 13, 2004 | url = http://www.scarletknights.com/football/news/release.asp?prID=15396#.VBUZhPmwL-s | accessdate = September 13, 2014 | archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20140914092102/http://www.scarletknights.com/football/news/release.asp?prID=15396#.VBUZhPmwL-s#.VBUZhPmwL-s | archive-date = 2014-09-14 | dead-url = yes | df = }} || Sept. 13, 2014 || Penn State 13, Rutgers 10 |- | 2 || 53,737 (sell-out){{cite web | title = CINCINNATI vs RUTGERS (Sep 07, 2009) | work = Official Website of Rutgers Athletics. | publisher = Rutgers, The State University of New Jersey | date = September 7, 2009 | url = http://scarletknights.com/football/stats/2009/9-7cin.htm | accessdate = May 4, 2010 | archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20100102140648/http://scarletknights.com/football/stats/2009/9-7cin.htm# | archive-date = 2010-01-02 | dead-url = yes | df = }} || Sept. 7, 2009 || Cincinnati 47, Rutgers 15 |- | 3 || 53,327 (sell-out){{cite web | title = MICHIGAN vs RUTGERS (Oct 04, 2014) | work = Official Website of Rutgers Athletics. | publisher = Rutgers, The State University of New Jersey | date = October 4, 2014 | url = http://www.scarletknights.com/sports/m-footbl/stats/2014-2015/ru06.html | accessdate = October 5, 2014}} || Oct. 5, 2014 || Rutgers 26, Michigan 24 |- | 4 || 53,111 (sell-out){{cite web | title = Barrett has 5 TDs in 1st start, OSU routs Rutgers - Summary (Oct 25, 2015) | work = espn.go.com. | publisher = ESPN | date = October 25, 2015 | url = http://espn.go.com/college-football/game?gameId=400763551 | accessdate = Nov 5, 2015}} || Oct. 25, 2015 || Ohio State 49, Rutgers 7 |- | 5 || 52,798 (sell-out){{cite web | title = UL vs RUTGERS (Nov 28, 2012) | work = NJ.com. | publisher = The Newark Star Ledger | date = November 28, 2012 | url = http://www.nj.com/rutgersfootball/index.ssf/2012/11/rutgers_announces_a_sellout_fo.html | accessdate = Nov 30, 2012}} || Nov. 29, 2012 || Louisville 20, Rutgers 17 |} ==Other events== In addition to football, HighPoint.com Stadium has been the home of Rutgers' men's and women's lacrosse teams since 2014. The stadium has also hosted [[National Collegiate Athletic Association|NCAA]] tournament [[college soccer|soccer]] and [[lacrosse (sport)#College lacrosse|lacrosse]] games, including the [[NCAA Men's Lacrosse Championship|NCAA Division I Men's Lacrosse Championship]] games in 1998, 2001, and 2002. It is also worth noting that, prior to 1994, the original Rutgers Stadium hosted the NCAA Division I Men's Lacrosse Championship games in 1974, 1978, 1983, 1987, and 1990. On September 25, 2005, Rutgers Stadium was the site of a lecture delivered by the [[Dalai Lama]].{{cite web | last = Alvarez | first = Ashanti | title = Dalai Lama charms, uplifts New Jersey | work = Rutgers Focus | publisher = Rutgers, The State University of New Jersey | date = October 10, 2005 | url = http://ur.rutgers.edu/focus/article/Dalai%20Lama%20charms,%20uplifts%20New%20Jersey/1639/ | accessdate = January 12, 2009 | archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20081113132547/http://ur.rutgers.edu/focus/article/Dalai%20Lama%20charms,%20uplifts%20New%20Jersey/1639/# | archive-date = 2008-11-13 | dead-url = yes | df = }} The stadium was a host venue for the [[1995 U.S. Cup]] soccer tournament and hosted [[Colombia national football team|Colombia]] vs. [[Nigeria national football team|Nigeria]] on June 17, 1995 and the [[United States Men's National Soccer Team|United States]] vs. Colombia on June 25, 1995. Every first weekend in December, Rutgers Stadium plays hosts to several championship games in the [[New Jersey State Interscholastic Athletic Association|NJSIAA]] state football playoffs. The stadium is one of two venues that hosts multiple championship games in one weekend ([[MetLife Stadium]] is the other). However, unlike MetLife Stadium that hosts games on Friday nights and Saturday afternoons, Rutgers hosts games on Sundays in addition to its Friday and Saturday games (MetLife Stadium is unavailable for Sunday games due to its [[National Football League|NFL]] commitments). Every year in October, Rutgers Stadium hosts USBands Marching Band New Jersey State Championships. Since 2011, University Commencement has been held in HighPoint.com Stadium each May. On May 15, 2016, President Obama addressed the class of 2016 and received an honorary degree of laws. Over 50,000 guests and graduates attended this historic day to celebrate the 250th Anniversary Commencement. ==See also== * [[List of NCAA Division I FBS football stadiums]] ==References== {{reflist|2}} ==External links== * {{Official website|http://www.scarletknights.com/football/stadium/stadium.asp}} {{S-start}} {{succession box | title = Host of the [[NCAA Division I Men's Soccer Championship|College Cup]] | years = 1989 | before = [[Bill Armstrong Stadium]] | after = [[USF Soccer Stadium]]}} {{s-end}} {{Rutgers Scarlet Knights football navbox}} {{Rutgers|New Brunswick}} {{Big Ten Conference football venue navbox}} {{New Jersey college football venues}} {{NewYorksportsvenues}} [[Category:College football venues]] [[Category:Rutgers Scarlet Knights football]] [[Category:NCAA Men's Division I Lacrosse Championship venues]] [[Category:Soccer venues in New Jersey]] [[Category:Lacrosse venues in the United States]] [[Category:College lacrosse venues in the United States]] [[Category:Sports venues in New Jersey]] [[Category:Sports venues in the New York metropolitan area]] [[Category:Multi-purpose stadiums in the United States]] [[Category:American football venues in New Jersey]] [[Category:Piscataway, New Jersey]] [[Category:1994 establishments in New Jersey]] [[Category:Sports venues completed in 1994]]

{{Infobox company | name = Hoshino Impul | logo = | type = | foundation = June 1980 | location = [[Setagaya-ku]], Tokyo | key_people = [[Kazuyoshi Hoshino]] (founder/president) | industry = [[Motorsport]]
Automotive [[engineering]] | products = Aluminum wheels, aerodynamics parts, suspensions, etc. Integrated, planning and development of car parts and accessories, manufacture and sales. Planning and development, manufacture and sales of complete automobiles primarily with Nissan | revenue = ¥1,297,000,000 (2006) | net_income = | num_employees = 287 (2006) | parent = | subsid = | homepage = [http://www.impul.co.jp/ Impul.co.jp] }} '''Hoshino Impul Co., Ltd.''', (known as '''Impul''') is a Japanese automotive aftermarket company based in [[Setagaya-ku]], Tokyo. Founded by [[Nissan]]'s factory driver, [[Kazuyoshi Hoshino]], the company exclusively produces aftermarket parts for Nissans, such as [[bodykit]]s, engine components as well as wheels. ==History== The company was founded in 1980 by the [[Nissan]] works driver, [[Kazuyoshi Hoshino]] in Maruko-cho, [[Shizuoka Prefecture]].{{cite web|title=Teams|url=http://www.f-nippon.co.jp/fn_eng/driversT/teams.php?t=05|publisher=F-Nippon (F-Japan)|accessdate=August 17, 2012}} Within months, Impul produced its first product, the ''IMPUL D-01'' wheel, which to promote it, it found its way on Hoshino's [[Group 5 (racing)|Gr. 5]] [[Nissan Silvia|Silvia]] racing competing in the Formula Silhouette, a [[Fuji Grand Champion]] support series, as well as starting a Tokyo-based sales center in Sayama-shi, [[Saitama-ken]]. A year later, that was relocated in [[Kichijōji]], Musashino-shi. In 1983, Hoshino formed Hoshino Racing Limited, a racing team to help promote his products and because of expansion, he relocated his company in Shimorenjaku, [[Mitaka, Tokyo|Mitaka]] as well as establishing a depot nearby. In 1987, Impul offered its first fully tuned car, the IMPUL 630R, a tuned Y31 [[Nissan Gloria|Gloria]]/[[Nissan Cedric|Cedric]]. In 2002, the racing relocated to [[Gotemba, Shizuoka]]. After that, the company began to focus on tuning cars and has since tuned the [[Infiniti M]], which became the Impul 6515,{{cite web|last=Tutu|first=Andrei|title=Infiniti M Becomes Impul 6515|url=http://www.autoevolution.com/news/infiniti-m-becomes-impul-651s-29679.html|publisher=AutoEvolution|accessdate=August 15, 2012}} and the [[Nissan Juke]].{{cite web|last=Radu|first=Mihnea|title=Tuning Overkill: Impul Gives Nissan Juke a Mugen Look|url=http://www.autoevolution.com/news/tuning-overkill-impul-gives-nissan-juke-a-mugen-look-36252.html|publisher=AutoEvolution|accessdate=August 17, 2012}} Both of these examples of Impul's tuning has changes to the bumpers, engines, brakes, tires, exhaust system, among other things. [[VIP style]] is the common element Impul has incorporated on. ==Motorsport== Since 1983, the company ran its own racing team which found success in domestic series such as [[Japanese Touring Car Championship|JTCC]], [[Formula Nippon]] and [[Super GT]]. Hoshino was the first driver to win in the team's [[Nissan Skyline GT-R|R32 GT-R]] during a JTCC race in 1990.{{cite web|title=Calsonic/Team Impul Fairlady Nissan 350Z|url=http://www.turbomagazine.com/features/0505tur_fairlady_nissan_350z/|publisher=Turbo Magazine|accessdate=August 17, 2012}} In addition to Hoshino, notable Impul drivers include [[Masahiko Kageyama]] (1993 Japanese Touring Car Championship winner), [[Satoshi Motoyama]] (2001, 2003 and 2005 Formula Nippon champion), [[Benoît Tréluyer]] (2006 Formula Nippon champion), [[Tsugio Matsuda]] (2007 and 2008 Formula Nippon champion), [[Yuji Ide]], and [[Kohei Hirate]]. Its primary sponsor since 1996 is auto parts supplier [[Calsonic]]. ==See also== * [[Nissan]] * [[Kazuyoshi Hoshino]] * [[Calsonic Kansei]] == References == {{Reflist}} ==External links== * {{Official website|http://www.impul.co.jp/}} {{Automotive industry in Japan}} [[Category:Formula Nippon teams]] [[Category:Japanese auto racing teams]] [[Category:Automotive companies based in Tokyo]] [[Category:Manufacturing companies based in Tokyo]] [[Category:Companies established in 1980]] [[Category:Wheel manufacturers]] [[Category:Automotive motorsports and performance companies]] [[Category:Japanese brands]] [[Category:Super GT teams]] {{Motorsport-stub}} {{Japan-sport-stub}}

revision.text:
[[Image:Bloemketerp072007 2.jpg|right|thumb|Girls playing 1-walled fronton]]
The '''International fronton''' is an ''indirect style'' [[ball game]] created to bring together some varieties (such as [[American handball]], [[Basque pelota]], [[Patball]], [[Gaelic handball]], [[Welsh handball|Pêl-Law (Welsh handball)]] and [[Valencian fronto|Valencian frontó]]), and to be played in the [[Handball International Championships]]. It is known as '''One Wall Handball'''.
== Courtfield == [[Image:Mkbaan.png|right|thumb|International Fronton courtfield]] ''International fronton'' takes back its courtfield to the most basic version of the indirect style: One wall where the ball must bounce.
This only wall, the [[Fronton (court)|fronton]], is 6,10m wide and 4,90m high. From the left and right corners two lines are drawn on the ground, 10,60m long, that mark the place into which the ball may bounce, this is the courtfield.
There must be some free space out the courtfield (1,80 wide) for the players to play balls that are risking to bounce twice.
At 4,90m from the fronton wall there is a line on the ground, the fault line. The serving player must throw the ball before that line, and the ball must surpass it after bouncing on the fronton.
At 10,60m from the fronton there is another line on the ground, the back line, which the ball may not bounce from.
In agreement with [[American handball]] (and unlike [[Basque pelota]] and [[Valencian fronto|Valencian frontó]]) there is no left or back wall, the ball may bounce on the lines, and, specially, there is no line on the fronton for the ball to ball over.
== Ball == The ''International fronton'' ball is a synthetic one, without any default colour. Diameter: 4,80 cm, weight: 65gr.
== Rules == Two players (1 against 1) or four players (2 against 2) play to score points until one of them attain two sets (composed by 21 points).
(In case of a tie, 1-1 sets, a third set is played, where the first service is done by the winner of the previous set)
Players strike the ball with the hand so that it bounces on the fronton and falls into the courtfield. Whoever fails to do so commits a fault and so loses a point, then the opponent serves.
A fault is committed if: * The player hits the ball with any other part of the body but the hand, * The ball doesn't bounce on the fronton, * The ball's first bounce on the ground is out the courtfield, * The player strikes the ball after a second bounce on the ground.
== See also == * [[Handball International Championships]] * [[American handball]] * [[Basque pelota]] * [[Gaelic handball]] * [[Welsh handball|Pêl-Law (Welsh handball)]] * [[Valencian fronto]]
== External links == * [http://www.baukefrans.nl/mk/enindex.html Muurkaatsen, 1-wall]
{{DEFAULTSORT:International Fronton}} [[Category:Ball games]] [[Category:Individual sports]] [[Category:Team sports]] [[Category:Valencian pilota competitions]]

{{Use dmy dates|date=February 2014}} {{Use Australian English|date=February 2014}} {{Infobox venue | stadium_name = Jubilee Stadium{{cite web|title=Jubilee Oval|url=http://www.dragons.com.au/news/2016/05/09/dragons_extend_partn.html|website=dragons.com.au|publisher=St. George Illawarra Dragons|accessdate=9 May 2016}} | nickname = Kogarah Stadium | image = [[File:OKI Jubilee Grandstand.jpg|250px|right]] | fullname = Jubilee Stadium | location = [[Sydney]], Australia | coordinates = {{coord|33|58|19|S|151|7|45|E|display=it}} | broke_ground = | built = | opened = 1936 | expanded = | closed = | demolished = | owner = [[Kogarah, New South Wales|Kogarah Council]] | operator = Georges River Council | surface = Grass | construction_cost = | architect = | seating_capacity = 20,505 (present){{cite web|title=Jubilee Oval|url=http://www.austadiums.com/stadiums/stadiums.php?id=59|website=austadiums.com|publisher=Austadiums|accessdate=13 November 2015}} | record_attendance = 23,582 - St George vs [[South Sydney Rabbitohs|South Sydney]], 1975 | dimensions = | former_names = | tenants = [[St. George Dragons]] ([[National Rugby League|NSWRL/ARL/NRL]]) (1936, 1950–1985, 1989–1998)
[[St. George Illawarra Dragons]] (NRL) (1999, 2003–2007, 2009–present)
[[Sydney Olympic FC]] ([[National Soccer League|NSL]]) (2003–2004)
[[Sydney FC]] ([[A-League]]) (2018-19) }} '''Jubilee Stadium''', also known as '''Kogarah Oval''', is a multipurpose stadium in [[Carlton, New South Wales|Carlton]], [[Sydney]], [[Australia]]. The stadium is primarily used for [[rugby league]] and secondary used for the [[A-League]], and is one of the home grounds of the [[National Rugby League]] (NRL) team [[St. George Illawarra Dragons]]. The stadium has hosted [[association football|soccer]] matches, including hosting [[Sydney Olympic FC]] in the [[National Soccer League]] (2003-04 season) and currently [[Sydney FC]] in the [[A-league]] (2018-19 season). The ground hosted its first game of rugby league in March 1936 when the [[St. George Dragons]] were defeated by the [[Newtown Jets|Newtown Bluebags]] in an exhibition match. The stadium has undergone several constructions over the years and one is still being planned for the foreseeable future. The first official game was played on 22 April 1950 in which the Dragons lost 17-15 to [[South Sydney Rabbitohs|South Sydney]].{{cite web | url=http://www.kogarah.nsw.gov.au/about-kogarah/sporting-history/jubilee-oval | archive-url=https://archive.is/20130219171505/http://www.kogarah.nsw.gov.au/about-kogarah/sporting-history/jubilee-oval | dead-url=yes | archive-date=19 February 2013 | title=Jubilee Oval - The history of Kogarah's iconic sports ground | publisher=Kogarah City Council | accessdate=28 January 2013}} Mapping software & websites when asked to find Kogarah Oval, Jubilee Stadium or Oval, often confuse the stadium with the Jubilee Park Oval located in [[Glebe, New South Wales]] on the [[Rozelle Bay]] foreshore. ==History== Jubilee Stadium currently stands on part of the original grant of {{convert|87|acre|m2}} awarded on 23 December 1853 to Archibald McNab. Edmund English purchased the grant on 23 May 1854 for around 400 pounds. It officially became known as Kogarah Park when it was acquired by the Department of Lands on 1 July 1896 and dedicated as the first public park in [[Kogarah, New South Wales|Kogarah]]. Control of the park was eventually passed to the Council of the Municipality of Kogarah on 29 August 1906. During Kogarah’s Jubilee celebrations in 1935, Jubilee Stadium was constructed in Kogarah Park. ==Development== The ground was closed from 1986 until the end of 1988 because of the construction of the new grandstand being built on the western side of the ground. During this time the Dragons played their home games at the [[Sydney Cricket Ground]] in [[1986 NSWRL season|1986]] and [[1987 NSWRL season|1987]], while using [[Belmore Oval]], the home of the [[Canterbury-Bankstown Bulldogs]], in [[1988 NSWRL season|1988]]. Since 2003, Jubilee Stadium has been steadily upgraded in a three-stage plan, funded by the NSW State Government and Federal Government. In 2006, the ground had been updated with new features to the seating around the grandstand and features directly out of the stadium including re-developments to the Hall of Fame walk and Kogarah Park in front of the stadium. Stage 1 consisted of new terraced seating at the north-western end, perimeter seating at the base of the hill, and a regrassed and raised hill area. Floodlights for televising night matches were also installed. In 2007, the Dragons announced that they would not be playing home games at Kogarah for the [[National Rugby League season 2008|2008 season]] so that Stage 2 redevelopment of the ground could be completed with new roofed extension on the Southern side of the main grandstand increasing capacity by around 2000, and further upgrading to the hill area, including turnstile facilities and strengthening the retaining wall at the Southern Jubilee Avenue end. The Dragons returned for 2009 against the Sharks in round 3, and broke the club record for highest Crowd at the ground. In 2010, the Dragons secured $13m from the NSW State Government to complete the Stage 3 Northern grandstand extension, with an additional 1580 seats and the replacement of 1730 seats in the existing main grandstand.[http://www.nrl.com/NewsViews/LatestNews/NewsArticle/tabid/10874/newsId/60603/Default.aspx $13 million Govt boost to upgrade WIN Jubilee Oval - NRL.com] Also included in the development are additional public toilets and facilities, refurbishment of the existing grandstand facilities including the team change rooms, a new passenger and service lift, additional corporate and multi purpose facilities, and a museum and merchandise store. A new digital scoreboard and several satellite scoreboards, new security system, turnstiles and ticketing facilities at Gate B and a rainwater harvesting tank were also installed around the ground during 2010 and 2011. {{cite web|url=http://www.dragons.com.au/default.aspx?s%3Darticle-display%26id%3D32333%26work-continuing-at-dragons-home-venues |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2010-12-14 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101215012516/http://www.dragons.com.au/default.aspx?s=article-display&id=32333&work-continuing-at-dragons-home-venues |archivedate=15 December 2010 |df=dmy }} ==Walk of Fame== In March 2004 a Legends Walk at Kogarah Oval was opened, with 16 club greats inducted into a hall of fame.{{cite news|last=Brad Walter and Steve Mascord|title=Broncos' teenage prodigy in the Hunt for a baptism of fire against the Warriors|url=http://newsstore.fairfax.com.au/apps/viewDocument.ac?page=1&sy=smh&kw=fame&pb=all_pubs&dt=enterRange&dr=1month&sd=05%2F03%2F2004&ed=08%2F03%2F2004&so=relevance&sf=text&sf=headline&rc=10&rm=200&sp=adv&clsPage=1&docID=SMH040308UB84E742UEE|accessdate=1 January 2014|newspaper=[[The Sydney Morning Herald]]|date=8 March 2004}} [[Brian Clay|Brian `Poppa` Clay]] • [[Mark Coyne (rugby league)|Mark Coyne]] • [[Reg Gasnier]] • [[Ken Kearney]] • [[Johnny King]] • [[Graeme Langlands]] • [[Eddie Lumsden]] • [[Matt McCoy (rugby league)|Matt McCoy]] • [[Noel Pidding]] • [[Norm Provan]] • [[John Raper]] • [[Rod Reddy|Rod `Rocket` Reddy]] • [[Kevin Ryan (rugby)|Kevin Ryan]] • [[Billy Smith (rugby league)|Billy Smith]] • [[Ian Walsh (rugby league)|Ian Walsh]] • [[Billy Wilson (rugby league)|Billy Wilson]] • [[Craig Young]] • Robert Stone ==Naming Rights== From 1950 until 2003, the ground was simply known as Jubilee Oval. In 2003, printing and data communications company [[Oki Electric Industry|OKI]] signed a five-year sponsorship deal for naming rights to the ground with the name becoming OKI Jubilee Stadium. In October, 2008, OKI Printing Solutions decided not to renew the naming rights of Jubilee Oval, as the Dragons played at [[ANZ Stadium]] during the 2008 season due to re-developments at Jubilee. The naming rights ended on 31 October with the park reverting to its former name.{{cite news|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110716135412/http://www.r2k.info/news/okiquitsjubilee2008.html|title=OKI quits Jubilee}} It was officially announced on 25 December 2008, that [[WIN Corporation]] had bought the naming rights for Jubilee Oval.{{cite news|url=http://stgeorge.yourguide.com.au/news/local/news/general/win-comes-to-jubilee-oval/1394165.aspx |title=WIN comes to Jubilee Oval |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081226225835/http://stgeorge.yourguide.com.au/news/local/news/general/win-comes-to-jubilee-oval/1394165.aspx |archivedate=26 December 2008 |df= }} With this agreement, WIN owned the naming rights to both of St. George Illawarra's home grounds, WIN Jubilee Oval and [[WIN Stadium]]. In early 2014, WIN backed out of this sponsorship, with the ground once again reverting to its original name. From 2016, the [[University of Wollongong]] held the rights to the ground for a two-year period, ending in late 2017. The ground was known as "UOW Jubilee Oval".{{cite web|url=http://www.dragons.com.au/news/2016/05/11/uow_jubilee_oval_ann.html|title=UOW Jubilee Oval Announcement|publisher=www.dragons.com.au|date=11 May 2016|accessdate=11 May 2016}} * Jubilee Oval (1950–2003, 2008, 2014 - 2015, 2018) * OKI Jubilee Stadium (2003–2008) * WIN Jubilee Oval (2009–2013) * UOW Jubilee Oval (2016-2017) * Jubilee Stadium (2018 - present)[https://www.theleader.com.au/story/5283961/jubilee-oval-to-be-renamed-a-stadium-as-council-seeks-new-sponsorship/ Jubilee Oval to be renamed a stadium as council seeks new sponsorship] St George Leader The ground is usually simply referred to as "Kogarah Oval" by the media and fans. ==Uses== ===Rugby league=== ====St. George DRLFC==== The [[St. George DRLFC]] which commenced competing in Sydney's top level in the [[1921 NSWRFL season]], had an unsuccessful debut game at Jubilee Oval in 1936 when they were defeated by [[Newtown Jets|Newtown]] in an exhibition match as part of the Jubilee celebrations.{{cite web | url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article17317594 | title=Rugby League - Exhibition Match | work=The Sydney Morning Herald | date=16 March 1936 | accessdate=28 January 2013}} The gate-takings from the match were donated to the St. George Hospital. Saints at this stage were still based at Arncliffe’s [[Earl Park, Arncliffe|Earl Park]] and it wasn’t until 1950 that Saints returned home to Jubilee Stadium. The Dragons played their first official match at the ground on 22 April 1950 against the [[South Sydney Rabbitohs]] before 12,500 fans. The Dragons lost a rather exciting match 17-15 but defeat would become quite a rare sight for the Dragons over the coming decades while at Kogarah. St. George were based at Kogarah during their world record breaking 11 successive premierships from 1956 to 1966. They set a record at Kogarah and were not beaten at home for an astonishing twelve years: originally beaten by the [[Balmain Tigers]] on 26 June 1954 at Kogarah which was just before the beginning of the streak. It wasn’t until 31 July 1966, that they tasted defeat at Kogarah again, eventually losing 12-9 to the [[Western Suburbs Magpies]]. In 1950, the Dragons began a permanent association with the ground. Around this time was also when St. George legend [[Norm Provan]] joined the club and he said of Kogarah: {{cquote|The qualities of the club from Kogarah are not easy for me to put into words... Saints are special. I will certainly never forget my years at Kogarah, and at the club across the Princes Highway. At St.George I found qualities that enriched my life - friendship, unswerving loyalty, fair play and healthy ambition, the learning to win, and to lose.}} The team was based at Jubilee Stadium right up until the completion of the 1985 season. They then chose to abandon the ground and relocated to the [[Sydney Cricket Ground]]. The decision was one which they would come to dread. In 1985 St. George had been Club champions, 1st Grade Minor premiers, 1st Grade Runners-Up, Reserve Grade Premiers and Under-23s Premiers. In 1986 Saints missed the semi-finals in all 3 grades for the first time in 50 years. The fans of the club became angry at the club's decision and stayed away from the club in droves while the Dragons remained at the SCG for a further season.{{Citation needed|date=March 2009}} In 1988 the opportunity came for the club to relocate again. Instead of moving back to Jubilee they decided to move to [[Belmore Sports Ground|Belmore Oval]]. Finally, in 1988 it was decided that the Saints would move home to Jubilee in 1989 with a new stand to be constructed for the 1990 season. The club yet again moved in the late 90's and explained to fans the decision was on the basis that Jubilee was too small to accommodate a proposed $30 million stadium complex to meet [[National Rugby League|NRL]] requirements for playing venues. In a joint statement, Kogarah Council and St. George DRLFC stated that the scale of the proposed 20,000 seat stadium would exceed the size of Jubilee Oval and affect residents. The decision to leave Jubilee upset many of St George Illawarra's loyal supporters as the ground had so much history to it and in July 2000 many supporters held a rally in support of the ground.{{Citation needed|date=March 2009}} ====St George Illawarra Dragons==== [[File:Jubilee Oval in 2018.jpg|thumb|right|A view of the ground prior to a match between the [[St. George Illawarra Dragons]] and [[Canterbury-Bankstown Bulldogs]] in August 2018.]] The [[St George Illawarra Dragons]], formed as the result of a merger between St George and the [[Illawarra Steelers]] in 1999, use Kogarah as one of their home grounds in the [[National Rugby League]], along with the Steelers former home, [[WIN Stadium]] in [[Wollongong]]. The newly formed Dragons used Kogarah in the [[1999 NRL season]], before moving their games to the [[Sydney Football Stadium]] (SFS) in 2000. From 2000 until 2002, after many loyal Dragons supporters held a rally and Information Night to persuade the club to move back to Jubilee Stadium (while at the SFS, the team had continued using WIN Stadium), the club did so and would be yet again occupying the famous [[Rugby league playing field|rugby league ground]]. During these 3 years that the Dragons did not play at Kogarah, there were talks with the club that they would play at the nearby [[St George Soccer Stadium]], but plans fell through and the soccer stadium has since fallen into disrepair. The Dragons returned to Kogarah in 2003 after a high number of protests and rallies held by supporter group R2K (or Return to Kogarah). Lights were installed at Kogarah in 2006, with the Dragons christening their first night game at the ground with an 8-1 win over the [[Parramatta Eels]] in Round 13 of the [[2006 NRL season|2006 season]]. The game was played in driving rain, which many gave as the reason for a crowd of only 9,075 in attendance. The club did not play at the ground in [[2008 NRL season|2008]] because of renovations of the south-western end grandstand being built. During this time, the Dragons played at [[Stadium Australia|ANZ Stadium]]. They returned to Kogarah in [[2009 NRL season|2009]], where they have remained ever since. ===Soccer=== [[Sydney Olympic FC]] played at Jubilee Stadium in their 2003/2004 season, competing in the [[National Soccer League]]. On 4 December 2011, it marked the first time an [[A-League]] club played a first grade competition game at the venue, with [[Sydney FC]] playing [[Brisbane Roar FC]], in front of a crowd of 11,555.[https://archive.is/20121230125906/http://www.footballaustralia.com.au/sydneyfc/news-display/Lavicka%20laments%20another%20slow%20start/43051 Lavicka laments another slow start], [[Football Federation Australia]], 28 November 2011. Retrieved on 30 November 2011. Sydney won 2-0, and this game itself would be remembered as the game the Roar lost its first match in the last 36 matches. In 2014, the [[St George FC|St George Saints]] got promoted to the [[NSW Premier League]], and moved to this ground as their home-ground stadium. Also, [[Sydney FC W-League|Sydney FC]] played a few games at this ground in the [[W-League (Australia)|W-League]] during their 2013/2014 season. The [[Socceroos]] have held several open training sessions at this ground since 2013. Sydney FC are using this ground as their primary home venue for the 2018-2019 A-League season, as their usual home ground, the [[Sydney Football Stadium]], is being demolished and a new stadium built on its site. The fan base showed great support for this - having a sellout 19,081 attend their first home match there, against [[Melbourne Victory]] 25 November 2018.[https://www.sydneyfc.com/news/sydney-fc-sell-out-bigblue-jubilee-stadium Sydney FC Sell Out #BigBlue At Jubilee Stadium] Sydney Football Club ==Transport== [[Carlton railway station, Sydney|Carlton railway station]] is located a few hundred metres from the ground. ==Attendance record== The ground record attendance for Jubilee Stadium was set in May 1975 when St. George took on South Sydney in front of 23,582 fans. In its modern form, the record attendance is 20,847 when the Dragons took on local rivals the [[Cronulla-Sutherland Sharks|Cronulla Sharks]] in March 2009. The record soccer match attendance was on 25 November, 2018, when Sydney FC took on Melbourne Victory in the A-League in front of a crowd of 19,081. ==References== {{Reflist|40em}} ==External links== *[http://www.dragons.com.au/ St. George Illawarra Dragons Official Site] *[http://www.r2k.info/ R2K - The definitive website on OKI Jubilee Stadium] *[http://www.r2k.info/locations/jubilee.html History of the Stadium] *[https://web.archive.org/web/20040212121339/http://www.r2k.info/lights.html Article on proposed construction to Jubilee] {{St. George Illawarra Dragons}} {{NRL Grounds}} {{Sydney FC W-League}} {{A-League stadiums}} [[Category:Rugby league stadiums in Australia]] [[Category:Sports venues in Sydney]] [[Category:Soccer venues in Australia]] [[Category:St. George Dragons]] [[Category:1936 establishments in Australia]] [[Category:Sports venues completed in 1936]] [[Category:W-League (Australia) stadiums]] [[Category:Sydney FC W-League]] [[Category:Kogarah, New South Wales]]

{{Infobox film | name = Kid Monk Baroni | image_size = | image = Kid Monk Baroni FilmPoster.jpeg | caption = | director = [[Harold D. Schuster]] | producer = [[Jack Broder]] (producer)
[[Herman Cohen]] (associate producer) | writer = [[Aben Kandel]] (original screenplay)
[[Dick Conway]] (additional dialogue) | narrator = | starring = See below | music = [[Herschel Burke Gilbert]] | cinematography = [[Charles Van Enger]] | editing = Jason H. Bernie | studio = Jack Broder Productions Inc. | distributor = [[Realart Pictures]] | released = {{film date|1952|5|1}} | runtime = 80 minutes | country = United States | language = English | budget = | gross = | preceded_by = | followed_by = | website = }} '''''Kid Monk Baroni''''' is a 1952 [[United States|American]] [[film noir]] directed by [[Harold D. Schuster]]. It is also known as '''''Young Paul Baroni''''' in the [[United Kingdom]] and is noted for being an early film appearance for [[Leonard Nimoy]], who would become famous for his role as [[Spock]] on the TV series ''[[Star Trek: The Original Series|Star Trek]]''. This film marks the first time that Nimoy played the lead role in a motion picture. ==Plot== A disfigured street kid ([[Leonard Nimoy]]) has plastic surgery and turns pro after a parish priest ([[Richard Rober]]) shows him how to box. ==Cast== [[File:Kid Monk Baroni 1.jpg|thumb|left|[[Kathleen Freeman]] and [[Leonard Nimoy]] ]] {{div col|colwidth=30em}} *[[Richard Rober]] as Father Callahan *[[Bruce Cabot]] as Mr. Hellman *[[Allene Roberts]] as Emily Brooks *[[Mona Knox]] as June Travers *[[Leonard Nimoy]] as Paul "Monk" Baroni *[[Jack Larson]] as Angelo *Budd Jaxon as Knuckles *Archer MacDonald as Pete *[[Kathleen Freeman]] as Maria Baroni *Joseph Mell as Gino Baroni *[[Paul Maxey]] as Mr. Al Petry *[[Stuart Randall (actor)|Stuart Randall]] as Mr. Moore *Chad Mallory as Tony *Ted Avery as Joey *Madelynn Broder as Little Girl in Church {{div col end}} == External links == {{commons category}} *{{IMDb title|id=0044796|title=Kid Monk Baroni}} *{{Rotten Tomatoes|kid_monk_baroni}} *{{Internet Archive film|id=Kid_Monk_Baroni|name=Kid Monk Baroni}} {{Harold D. Schuster}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Kid Monk Baroni}} [[Category:1952 films]] [[Category:1950s drama films]] [[Category:1950s sports films]] [[Category:American films]] [[Category:American drama films]] [[Category:American sports films]] [[Category:English-language films]] [[Category:American black-and-white films]] [[Category:Boxing films]] [[Category:Films directed by Harold D. {{Infobox handball club | clubname = '''HC Gjorče Petrov ''' | image = KometalGjorcePetrov logo.png | full name = Ženski rakometen klub
Gjorče Petrov | founded = 1979 | ground = [[Kocho Racin]] | capacity = 1000 | owner = Apolo Inzinering C.O | chairman = | manager = | league = [[Macedonian women's First League of Handball|Skopsko Super League]] | season = 2014–15 | position = Skopsko Super League | website = | colour1 =Yellow|colour2=Black | pattern_la1=|pattern_b1=|pattern_ra1=| leftarm1=000000|body1=000000|rightarm1=000000|shorts1=FFFF00|socks1=FFFFFF| pattern_la2=|pattern_b2=|pattern_ra2=| leftarm2=FFFF00|body2=FFFF00|rightarm2=FFFF00|shorts2=FFFFFF|socks2=FFFFFF| }} '''Kometal Gjorče Petrov Skopje''' ({{lang-mk|Ракометен Клуб Кометал Ѓорче Петров}}) was a female [[Team handball|handball]] club based in [[Skopje]], the capital of [[Republic of Macedonia|Macedonia]]. == History == The club was founded in 1979 under the name ''Handball Club Gjorče Petrov''.{{cite web |url=http://www.wrhl.info/2008072356/Newsflash/represent-kometal-gjorce-petrov.html |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2008-09-07 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080907200345/http://www.wrhl.info/2008072356/Newsflash/represent-kometal-gjorce-petrov.html |archivedate=2008-09-07 |df= }} Since 1992, it had won 17 national championships 16 national cups, losing only the cup in 1994. The club won the EHF Champions League back in 2002 when they defeated [[Women's EHF Champions League|Champions League]] [[Ferencvárosi TC]].http://www.ehfcl.com/women/2001-02/rounds/7 They were also finalists in 2000 and 2005, and won the [[EHF Women's Champions Trophy|Champions Trophy]] once in 2002.http://www.ehfcl.com/women/2008-09/clubs/1987/HC+Kometal+Gjorce+Petrov At one time, it was the most popular sports team in the country, having its own anthem song by Macedonian musicians and entertainers.https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=PVt3X7Q6EsQ Kometal Gjorče Petrov stopped its work on 16 September 2011 when the central committee decided that there was no conditions for operation and existence.http://www.dw.de/dw/article/0,,15957546,00.html{{cite web |url=http://www.kirilica.com.mk/vest.asp?id=66405 |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2011-10-17 |deadurl=yes to work and now exists as ZRK Gjorche and competes in Macedonian women's First League of Handball .It was shut for couple of years but it started working again,without its brandmark Kometal. == Accomplishments == * '''[[Macedonian women's First League of Handball|Championship of Macedonia]]:''' :''Winners (17):'' 1993, 1994, 1995, 1996, 1997, 1998, 1999, 2000, 2001, 2002, 2003, 2004, 2005, {{about|the Furman University baseball venue|the Elon University baseball venue|Walter C. Latham Park}} {{Infobox stadium | name = Latham Baseball Stadium | nickname = | image = | fullname = John T. and Gloria Latham Baseball Stadium | former_names = Furman Baseball Stadium (1956-2008) | location = 1612 Duncan Chapel Road, [[Greenville, South Carolina|Greenville]], [[South Carolina|SC]], [[United States of America|USA]] | coordinates = {{coord|34.921472|-82.44256|display=title,inline}} | broke_ground = | built = 1956 | opened = March 20, 1956 | renovated = 1998, 2001 | expanded = | closed = | demolished = | owner = [[Furman University]] | operator = | surface = Natural [[grass]] | scoreboard = Electronic | estimated_cost = | suites = | architect = | project_manager = | structural engineer = | services engineer = | general_contractor = | main_contractors = | capacity = 2,000 | record_attendance = | executive_suites = | dimensions = 330 ft. ([[Left field|LF]]), 350 ft. (LCF), 393 ([[Baseball field#outfield|CF]]), 371 ft. (RCF), 330 ft. ([[Right field|RF]]) | acreage = | tenants = [[Furman University]] Paladins [[college baseball]] ([[Southern Conference]]) (1956-present) }}
'''Latham Baseball Stadium''' is a [[baseball]] [[Baseball field|venue]] located in [[Greenville, South Carolina|Greenville]], [[South Carolina]], [[United States of America|USA]]. It is home to the [[Furman University|Furman]] Paladins [[college baseball]] team. The venue opened in 1956 and has a capacity of 2,000 spectators.<ref name="facil">[http://www.furmanpaladins.com/athletics/facilities/latham_baseball_stadium Latham Baseball Stadium], URL accessed December 11, 2010. [https://www.webcitation.org/5ututgHCN Archived] 12-11-2010</ref>
==Naming==
The stadium is named after Tommy Latham and his family. Latham was an All-Conference baseball player at Furman. The venue was renamed and dedicated to him and his family in May 2008 prior to a conference game against [[Davidson Wildcats|Davidson]], with the park's full name becoming '''John T. and Gloria Latham Baseball Stadium''' (John and Gloria Latham are the parents of the Paladin baseball player Tommy). The Latham family made a contribution of [[USD|$]]1 million for the park to be renamed.<ref name="dedication">[https://www.ncaa.com/sports/m-basebl/spec-rel/043008aap.html Furman To Dedicate Latham Baseball Stadium This Saturday] at ncaa.com, URL accessed December 11, 2010. [https://www.webcitation.org/5utv3bsUg Archived] 12-11-2010</ref> Prior to the renaming, the field had been known as '''Furman Baseball Stadium''' since its construction in 1956.<ref name="facil" />
==Features== In 1997, the field's seating areas were renovated, with 300 permanent stadium seats being added behind [[home plate]]. In 2001, lights were added to the facility, allowing night games to be played for the first time. The first night game was played on April 13, 2001, against [[UNC Greensboro Spartans|UNC Greensboro]]. In 2006, [[batting cage]] was added to the facility; it is located down the [[left field]] line. The stadium also features a [[press box]], scoreboard, and expanded [[dugout (baseball)|dugout]]s.<ref name="facil" />
==See also== * [[List of NCAA Division I baseball venues]]

{{Use mdy dates|date=February 2013}} {{Infobox venue | stadium_name = McCormick Field | nickname = | logo_image = [[File:McCormickField.PNG|200px]] | image = [[File:McCormick Field entrance.JPG|250px]] | location = 30 Buchanan Place
[[Asheville, North Carolina|Asheville, NC]] 28801 | coordinates = {{coord|35|35|14|N|82|32|57|W|type:landmark|display=inline,title}} | broke_ground = 1923 | built = | opened = April 3, 1924 | renovated = 1959, 1992 | expanded = | closed = | owner = [[Asheville, North Carolina|City of Asheville]] | operator = [[Asheville Tourists|DeWine Seeds Silver Dollar Baseball, LLC.]] | surface = Natural Grass | construction_cost = [[United States dollar|$]]200,000
(${{formatprice|{{Inflation|US|200000|1924}}}} in {{Inflation-year|US}} dollars{{inflation-fn|US}}) | architect = Bowers, Ellis, and Watson{{cite web |title=McCormick Field|url=http://www.heritagewnc.org/bibliography/buildings/mccormick_field.htm|publisher=University of North Carolina at Asheville|accessdate=September 17, 2011|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120415073745/http://www.heritagewnc.org/bibliography/buildings/mccormick_field.htm|archivedate=April 15, 2012}} | general_contractor= Leader Construction | main_contractors = | tenants = [[Asheville Tourists]] ([[South Atlantic League|SAL]]) (1924–present)
[[UNC Asheville Bulldogs]] ([[Big South Conference|BSC]])
[[Big South Conference Baseball Tournament|Big South Tournament]] (2009)
[[Asheville Blues]] ([[Negro Southern League (1945–51)|NSL]]) (1940s) | seating_capacity = 4,000 | dimensions = Left Field: 326 feet (99.4 m)
Left-Center: 370 feet (112.8 m)
Center Field: 373 feet (113.7 m)
Right-Center: 320 feet (97.5 m)
Right Field: 297 feet (90.5 m) }} '''McCormick Field''' is a [[baseball]] [[stadium]] in [[Asheville, North Carolina]]. It is the home field of the [[Asheville Tourists]] [[minor league baseball]] team. As befits the hilly city of Asheville, the ballpark sits on a section of level ground partway up one of the city's hills, providing a picturesque atmosphere. {{cite news |title=On Base with the Asheville Tourists|first=Keith|last=Jarrett|url=http://blogs.citizen-times.com/blogs/index.php?blog=12&p=237&more=1&c=1&tb=1&pb=1|newspaper=[[Asheville Citizen Times]]|date=May 14, 2007|accessdate=April 5, 2011|archiveurl=https://archive.is/20110812172245/http://blogs.citizen-times.com/blogs/index.php?blog=12&p=237&more=1&c=1&tb=1&pb=1|archivedate=August 12, 2011}} It is the oldest minor-league park in regular use. ==History== The ballpark was built in 1924 and was named after Asheville resident Lewis McCormick; it is one of the oldest minor-league stadiums still in regular use. Lights were installed for nighttime play prior to the 1930 season. Since then, it has been home to the various incarnations of the Asheville Tourists team, and also served as home field for the [[Asheville Blues]] of the [[Negro Southern League (1945–51)|Negro Southern League]] during the 1940s.{{cite web |title=Ballparks of the Negro Leagues and Barnstorming Black Baseball Teams|url=http://www.nlbpa.com/ballparks.html|publisher=Negro League Baseball Players Association|accessdate=June 17, 2009|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090610073533/http://www.nlbpa.com/ballparks.html|archivedate=June 10, 2009}} The facility was renovated in 1959, and then rebuilt in concrete between the 1991 and 1992 seasons, replacing the largely wood structure which had developed a leaky roof. The 1992 ballpark kept a similar layout to the original McCormick Field. The facility included new expanded restrooms and larger concession stands. New clubhouses were built and lights erected as player and field enhancements. The height of the fence behind the cozy right field area, which was in the vicinity of just {{convert|300|ft|m}} away from home plate, was more than tripled, as it now stands {{convert|36|ft|m}} tall (nearly the same height as [[Fenway Park]]'s "[[Green Monster]]").{{cite web |title=History of McCormick Field|first=Bill|last=Ballew|url=http://www.milb.com/news/article.jsp?ymd=20131119&content_id=64045212&fext=.jsp&vkey=news_t573&sid=t573|publisher=Minor League Baseball|date=November 19, 2013|accessdate=May 30, 2014}} [[File:McCormick Field from Memorial Stadium.JPG|left|thumb|150px]] ==Other uses== The ballpark served as one of the settings for the 1988 film ''[[Bull Durham]]''.{{cite news |title=Local Men Recall 'Bull Durham' Roles|first=Keith|last=Jarrett|url=http://www.citizen-times.com/article/20130616/SPORTS/306160059/|newspaper=[[Asheville Citizen Times]]|date=June 16, 2013|accessdate=May 30, 2014}} The venue hosted the 2009 [[Big South Conference Baseball Tournament]], won by [[Coastal Carolina Chanticleers baseball|Coastal Carolina]].{{cite web|title=Coastal Carolina Wins Big South Baseball Championship |url=http://www.bigsouthsports.com/ViewArticle.dbml?DB_OEM_ID=4800&ATCLID=3742296 |publisher=Big South Conference |accessdate=February 18, 2012 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140531125623/http://www.bigsouthsports.com/ViewArticle.dbml?DB_OEM_ID=4800&ATCLID=3742296 |archivedate=May 31, 2014 |date=May 23, 2009 |deadurl=yes |df= }} Farther up the hill, behind the left field area, is Asheville Memorial Stadium, a football and soccer facility. Its bleacher seating structure is visible from McCormick Field. ==See also== * [[List of NCAA Division I baseball venues]] ==References== {{reflist|2}} ==External links== *[http://www.ballparkreviews.com/ashev/ashev.htm Photos of the ballpark] *[http://www.littleballparks.com/Stadium/2011/Asheville/Asheville.htm McCormick Field Views – ''Ball Parks of the Minor Leagues''] {{SAL ballparks}} {{Big South Conference baseball venue navbox}} {{WNC sports venues}} [[Category:Minor league baseball venues]] [[Category:Sports venues in North Carolina]] [[Category:UNC Asheville Bulldogs baseball]] [[Category:Baseball venues in North Carolina]] [[Category:Negro league baseball venues]] [[Category:Negro league baseball venues still standing]] [[Category:Buildings and structures in Asheville, North Carolina]] [[Category:Tourist attractions in Asheville, North Carolina]] [[Category:1924 establishments in North Carolina]] [[Category:Sports venues completed in 1924]] [[Category:College baseball venues in the United States]]

{{NBA Awards}} The '''NBA All-Rookie Team''' is an annual [[National Basketball Association]] (NBA) honor given since the [[1962–63 NBA season]] to the top [[rookie]]s during the regular season. Voting is conducted by the [[List of NBA head coaches|NBA head coaches]]; who are not allowed to vote for players on their own team.{{cite web|url=http://www.nba.com/news/all_rookie_080513.html|title=Durant, Horford Headline T-Mobile All-Rookie Team|accessdate=August 13, 2008|date=May 14, 2008|publisher=Turner Sports Interactive, Inc|work=NBA.com}} The All-Rookie Team is generally composed of two five-man lineups, a first team and a second team. The players each receive two points for each first team vote and one point for each second team vote. The top five players with the highest point total make the first team, with the next five making the second team. In the case of a tie at the fifth position of either team, the roster is expanded. If the first team consists of six players due to a tie, the second team will still consist of five players with the potential for more expansion in the event of additional ties. Ties have occurred several times, most recently in 2012, when [[Kawhi Leonard]], [[Iman Shumpert]], and [[Brandon Knight (basketball)|Brandon Knight]] tied in votes received. No respect is given to positions. For example, the first team had four [[Forward (basketball)|forwards]], and one [[Guard (basketball)|guard]] in 2008, while the first team had four [[Center (basketball)|centers]] (two of which were [[forward-center]]s) and one guard in 2016. Nine All-Rookie Team members have won both the [[NBA Rookie of the Year Award|Rookie of the Year Award]] and the [[NBA Most Valuable Player|Most Valuable Player Award]] (MVP) during their careers. [[Wilt Chamberlain]] and [[Wes Unseld]] are the only players to accomplish this feat in the same season. As of the end of the {{nbay|2007|app=season}}, 29 members of the All-Rookie Team have been elected into the [[Naismith Memorial Basketball Hall of Fame]], 28 members were not born in the United States and 120 members are active in the NBA.{{cite web|url=http://www.nba.com/history/awards_rookieofyear.html|title=Rookie of the Year|publisher=Turner Sports Interactive, Inc|work=NBA.com|accessdate=September 6, 2008}}{{cite web|url=http://www.nba.com/history/awards_mvp.html|title=Most Valuable Player|publisher=Turner Sports Interactive, Inc|work=NBA.com|accessdate=September 6, 2008}}{{cite web|url=http://www.hoophall.com/hall-of-famers-index/|title=Hall of Famers|publisher=Hoophall.com|accessdate=September 17, 2011}}{{cite web|url=http://www.nba.com/players/int_players_0708.html|title=NBA Players From Around The World: 2007-08 Season|publisher=Turner Sports Interactive, Inc|work=NBA.com|accessdate=September 6, 2008}}{{cite web|url=http://www.nba.com/players/|title=Players|publisher=Turner Sports Interactive, Inc|work=NBA.com|accessdate=September 6, 2008}} ==Selections== {| class="wikitable" |- | style="background:#cfecec; border:1px solid #aaa; width:6em;"| ^ |Denotes players who are still active in the NBA |- | style="background:#ff9; border:1px solid #aaa; width:6em;"| * |Elected to the [[Naismith Memorial Basketball Hall of Fame]] as a player |- |'''Player'''
(in bold text) |Indicates the player who won the [[NBA Rookie of the Year Award|Rookie of the Year]] award |- |''Player''
(in italic text) |Indicates the player who was drafted [[List of first overall NBA draft picks|first overall]] |} {{clear}} [[Image:Kareem Abdul Jabbar crop.jpg|upright|thumb|[[Kareem Abdul-Jabbar]] (as Lew Alcindor) was named to the All-Rookie Team in the [[1969–70 NBA season]].|alt=head shot of Kareem Abdul Jabbar]] [[Image:Larrybird.jpg|upright|thumb|[[Larry Bird]] was named to the All-Rookie Team in the [[1979–80 NBA season]].|alt=head shot of Larry Bird]] [[Image:Magic Lipofsky.jpg|upright|thumb|[[Magic Johnson]] was named to the All-Rookie Team in the [[1979–80 NBA season]].|alt=Magic his name to Kareem Abdul-Jabbar.{{cite web|url=http://www.nba.com/history/players/abduljabbar_bio.html|title=Kareem Abdul-Jabbar Bio|accessdate=August 4, 2008|publisher=Turner Sports Interactive, Inc|work=NBA.com}} *{{note label|Note2|b|b}} When Olajuwon arrived in the United States, the University of Houston incorrectly spelled his first name "Akeem". Olajuwon used that spelling until March 9, 1991, when he announced that he would add an H.{{cite web|url=http://www.nba.com/playerfile/hakeem_olajuwon/bio.html |title=Hakeem Olajuwon Bio: 1992–93 |accessdate=June 15, 2008 |publisher=Turner Sports Interactive, Inc |work=NBA.com |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080516203041/http://www.nba.com/playerfile/hakeem_olajuwon/bio.html |archivedate=May 16, 2008 |df= }}{{cite news| first=Chris|last=Dufresne|title= Hakeem Still Can Be Called 'the Dream'|work= [[Los Angeles Times]]|page= 2|date= March 11, 1991}} *{{note label|Note3|c|c}} Richard Dumas was originally drafted in 1991, but due to drug violations, he was suspended for the entire {{nbay|1991|app=season}}. His rookie season began in the {{nbay|1992|app=season}}. *{{note label|Note4|d|d}} Ron Artest changed his name to Metta World Peace on September 16, 2011.{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/aponline/2011/09/16/sports/basketball/AP-BKN-Artest-Name-Change.html|title=Artest's Name Change to Metta World Peace Approved|accessdate=September 16, 2011|date=September 16, 2011|publisher=|work=The New York Times}} *{{note label|Note5|e|e}} Amar'e Stoudemire's first name had previously been spelled incorrectly as "Amaré" or "Amare" since joining the NBA, but was changed to "Amar'e" in October 2008.{{cite news|url=http://www.azcentral.com/arizonarepublic/sports/articles/2008/10/30/20081030spt-bickley.html|title=Bickley on Amaré: Awaking the giant|first=Dan|last=Bickley|work=[[The Arizona Republic]]|date=October 30, 2008|accessdate=March 25, 2009}}{{cite news|url=http://www.nba.com/2008/news/features/dave_mcmenamin/11/20/112008amareqa/index.html|title=Change the name of the game for Stoudemire this season|first=Dave|last=McMenamin|publisher=Turner Sports Interactive, Inc|work=NBA.com|date=November 20, 2008|accessdate=March 25, 2009}} *{{note label|Note6|f|f}} Blake Griffin was drafted in 2009, but injured his left kneecap in a pre-season game before the {{nbay|2009|app=season}}. He underwent surgery in January 2010 and missed the entire season. His rookie season began in the {{nbay|2010|app=season}}.{{cite web|url=http://sports.espn.go.com/los-angeles/nba/news/story?id=4823032|title=Griffin's rookie season lost to injury|accessdate=January 13, 2010|work=ESPN.com|date=January 13, 2010}} *{{note label|Note7|g|g}} Jonas Valančiūnas was drafted in 2011, but due partially to the [[2011 NBA lockout]], he spent the entire {{nbay|2011|app=season}} in his home nation of [[Lithuania]]. His rookie season began in the {{nbay|2012|app=season}}. *{{note label|Note8|h|h}} Nenê Hilario changed his name to simply Nenê in on August 6, 2003.http://www.nba.com/nuggets/news/nene_namechange_030806.html *{{note label|Note9|i|i}} Ben Simmons was drafted in 2016, but injured his right foot and was ruled out of the entire season. His rookie season began in the {{nbay|2017|app=season}}. {{refend}} ==References== ;General {{refbegin}} *{{cite web|url=http://www.nba.com/history/awards_allrookieteams.html|title=All-Rookie Teams|accessdate=August 13, 2008|last=|first=|date=|publisher=Turner Sports Interactive, Inc|work=NBA.com}} *{{cite web|url=https://www.basketball-reference.com/awards/all_rookie.html|title=All-Rookie Teams|accessdate=August 13, 2008|last=|first=|date=|work=basketball-reference.com}} {{refend}} ;Specific {{reflist|30em}} {{featured list}} [[Category:National Basketball Association awards|All-Rookie Team]] [[Category:National Basketball Association lists]] [[Category:Awards established in 1963]] [[Category:Rookie player awards]]

[[Papua New Guinea Hunters]] ([[Queensland Cup]] 2016-present) | embedded = | website = | publictransit = }} '''PNG Football Stadium''' (known as Lloyd Robson Oval until 2015){{cite web|title=PNG National Football Stadium|url=http://populous.com/project/png-national-football-stadium/|publisher=Populous|accessdate=12 June 2017}} is a sporting ground in [[Port Moresby]], [[Papua New Guinea]]. It hosted 3 games for the [[1989–1992 Rugby League World Cup]]. It has been the home ground for the [[Papua New Guinea national rugby league team]] since 1975. It has a total capacity of approximately 15,000 and is the National Stadium of Papua New Guinea. The stadium was completely redeveloped in preparation for the [[2015 Pacific Games]]. ==History== Lloyd Robson Oval hosted its first [[Rugby League]] international on 6 July 1975 when PNG played host to [[England national rugby league team|England]] who were on their way to [[Australia]] and [[New Zealand]] for the down under leg of the [[1975 Rugby League World Cup|1975 World Cup]]. In front of an enthusiastic crowd of 12,000 England ran out 40-12 winners in what was the Kumuls international debut game. PNG played the [[1982 Kangaroo tour|1982]] and [[1986 Kangaroo tour|1986]] [[Australian Kangaroos|Kangaroos]] at the oval. The Australians, unbeaten on both [[Kangaroo Tour]]s, won both games 38-2 and 62-12 respectively. The 1986 game saw the Oval's record attendance when 17,000 enthusiastic fans saw the Kangaroos defeat the Kumuls. The opening Test match of the [[1988 Great Britain Lions tour]] was played at the Oval between Papua New Guinea and the British before a crowd of 12,107. Lloyd Robson Oval was the primary venue of the [[2009 Pacific Cup]]. The four round-robin matches were played at the ground on 24–25 October and 31 October, with the final played on 1 November 2009.{{Cite web|url=http://www.australianrugbyleague.com.au/news/article.php?id=1323 |publisher=Australian Rugby League |title=Pacific Cup announced |author=ARL (Press Release) |date=2009-07-28 |accessdate=2009-07-29 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090913135900/http://www.australianrugbyleague.com.au/news/article.php?id=1323 |archivedate=2009-09-13 |df= }} The oval is also home of the [[Gulf Isapea]], [[Hela Wigmen]], and [[Port Moresby Bulldogs]] who play in the [[Papua New Guinea National Rugby League|PNGNRL Digitel Cup]]. Lloyd Robson is also a regular host of the annual rugby league game between the Kumuls and an [[Prime Minister's XIII|Australian Prime Minister's XIII]] at the conclusion of the Australian-based [[National Rugby League]] season. These games are usually well attended, with 16,000 attending the game in 2012 won 24-18 by the [[Mal Meninga]] coached PM's XIII. [[Soccer]] is also played at the Lloyd Robson Oval, with both the national men's and women's PNG teams playing matches at the ground, though they both generally use the [[Hubert Murray Stadium]] ==Rugby league test matches== List of rugby league test matches played at Lloyd Robson Oval.[http://www.rugbyleagueproject.org/venues/lloyd-robson-oval/results.html Lloyd Robson Oval @ Rugby League Project] {| class="wikitable" |- bgcolor=#bdb76b !
